actions-list.actionItem: The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 546.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Hunt moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. S. 546 — "To amend the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to authorize law enforcement agencies to use COPS grants for recruitment activities, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 3950.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 3950 — "To require sellers of event tickets to disclose comprehensive information to consumers about ticket prices and related fees, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6132.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 6132 — "To require the Consumer Product Safety Commission to promulgate a mandatory consumer product safety standard with respect to retractable awnings."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6572.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 6572 — "To direct the Secretary of Commerce to take actions necessary and appropriate to promote the competitiveness of the United States related to the deployment, use, application, and competitiveness of blockchain technology or other distributed ledger technology, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6571.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 6571 — "To establish a critical supply chain resiliency and crisis response program in the Department of Commerce, and to secure American leadership in deploying emerging technologies, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 5390.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 5390 — "To direct the Secretary of Commerce to conduct a study on the feasibility of manufacturing in the United States products for critical infrastructure sectors, and for other purposes."
The title of the measure was amended. Agreed to without objection.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 4814.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 4814 — "To direct the Consumer Product Safety Commission to establish a pilot program to explore the use of artificial intelligence in support of the mission of the Commission and to direct the Secretary of Commerce and the Federal Trade Commission to study and report on the use of blockchain technology and digital tokens, respectively."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1797.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 1797 — "To require the Consumer Product Safety Commission to promulgate a consumer product safety standard with respect to rechargeable lithium-ion batteries used in micromobility devices, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6960.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Bucshon moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 6960 — "To amend the Public Health Service Act to reauthorize the Emergency Medical Services for Children program."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 4581.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Bucshon moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 4581 — "To amend title V of the Social Security Act to support stillbirth prevention and research, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 4310.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 4310 — "To ban the sale of products with a high concentration of sodium nitrite to individuals, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 4510.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Latta moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 4510 — "To reauthorize the National Telecommunications and Information Administration, to update the mission and functions of the agency, and for other purposes."
The Speaker announced that votes on suspensions, if ordered, will be postponed until a time to be announced.

The House received a message from the Acting Clerk. Under Clause 2(g) of Rule II of the Rules of the U.S. House of Representatives, the Acting Clerk notified the House of his designation of Ms. Lisa P. Grant, Deputy Clerk, Ms. Sarah Meier, Legal Counsel, and Ms. Cheryl H. Muller, Director of Personnel, to sign any and all papers and perform all other acts for him under the name of the Acting Clerk of the House for which they would be authorized to do by virtue of the designation, except such as are provided by statute, in case of his temporary absence or disability and that this designation shall remain in effect for the 118th Congress, or until modified by him.
The House proceeded with one minute speeches.
The Chair designated Mr. Latta to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of May 14.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 2:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 2:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Larry Bucshon to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
